lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about beach safety and find key details about what is and isn’t safe.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Read the beach safety text aloud. Ask: “Is it safe to swim alone?” Students find and underline the answer in the SB.
stretchStrategies: ❝Safety Poster Challenge❞ – Students work in pairs to draw a beach safety tip and write a short sentence using known phonics sounds (e.g., “Be in the shade.”). Share posters with the class.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can trace and write the letter combinations “th” and “ee” to form simple words.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say /th/ and /ee/ sounds. Write “three,” “teeth,” “the” on the board. Students repeat, then trace letters in notebooks.
stretchStrategies: ❝Safety Poster Challenge❞ – Students work in pairs to draw a beach safety tip and write a short sentence using known phonics sounds (e.g., “Be in the shade.”). Share posters with the class.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can learn how to stay safe at the beach and explain one safety rule to a friend.
supportStrategies: (Health) Draw two columns on the board: Safe / Not Safe. Students sort actions from the reading into the correct column.
stretchStrategies: ❝Safety Poster Challenge❞ – Students work in pairs to draw a beach safety tip and write a short sentence using known phonics sounds (e.g., “Be in the shade.”). Share posters with the class.

items: Certain common holiday activities are less likely to overlap with those of Western kids (eating seafood at the beach, going on tours in large groups)
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
